title: AI Act
summary: The AI Act is a new legislation that aims to regulate the development, distribution, and use of artificial intelligence. It represents the first global attempt to discipline the use of AI, setting a model for other jurisdictions. The normative aims to create a legal framework that balances innovation with fundamental rights protection, such as privacy and security. Conformity to the AI Act is a priority for organizations operating with AI systems in the EU or entering the market.

title: AI Literacy - Questions & Answers on Article 4 and the AI Act
summary: This document provides answers to questions about Article 4 of the AI Act, which outlines requirements for providers and deployers of AI systems to ensure their staff and representatives have sufficient AI literacy. The concept of AI literacy is defined as skills, knowledge, and understanding that enable informed deployment of AI systems and awareness of opportunities, risks, and potential harm. The target group includes anyone in the organization directly dealing with an AI system.
key_concepts: Providers and deployers of AI systems should ensure a sufficient level of AI literacy among their staff and representatives.
AI literacy is defined as skills, knowledge, and understanding that allow for informed deployment of AI systems.
The target group includes anyone in the organization directly dealing with an AI system.
AI literacy helps stakeholders make informed decisions about the deployment of AI systems and understand potential risks and opportunities.
content_preview: Ensuring AI literacy among staff is key for providers and deployers under the AI Act.

summary: Social engineering is a confidence scam that convinces unsuspecting people to provide information to bad people trying to steal their information. It's often the first step in an attack and can be underestimated due to its non-technical nature. Between 66 and 84 percent of network intrusions contain a social engineering factor, and personal information has been stolen from almost everyone who has used a computer.
key_concepts: A confidence scam that convinces people to provide information to bad actors.
The first step in a complex attack, often underestimated due to its non-technical nature.
Between 66 and 84% of network intrusions contain a social engineering factor.
Personal information is often stolen through hacks, affecting almost everyone who has used a computer.
Social networks have made sharing personal information an art.
SSH brute force attack involves finding an open SSH server and using a tool to guess passwords.
Running SSH on a non-standard port can prevent novice hackers from accessing the system.

title: AI in Africa: A Landscape Study
summary: This report analyses the current state of AI in Africa, including opportunities, challenges, governance, economic trends, and stakeholder roles. It highlights best practices for building sustainable and ethical AI systems to achieve sustainable and ethical AI systems through governance, implementation, and leveraging opportunities for collaborations. Africa has a young, linguistically diverse and increasingly digitally literate population, which presents opportunities for Africans to be AI active innovators and informed contributors rather than mere consumers of technologies. Achieving this requires investment in adequate resources to strengthen local and regional agency, and enhancing digital skills. It also requires addressing the continent’s dependency on other countries, extraction of material and human expertise and training data biases that misrepresent African contexts and perspectives. Though comprehensive AI regulation is still nascent in Africa, there is an increased focus on national AI strategies, ethical considerations, and responsible AI practices.
key_concepts: Opportunities and challenges in African AI adoption
Importance of governance in AI development
Addressing digital skills gap in Africa
Need for comprehensive AI regulation in Africa
Growing AI market size in Africa to $16.5 billion by 2030
Africa's adoption of cloud technology outpacing global average
Emergence of a market grounded in and responding to continental and local needs
Locally designed technologies for better financial inclusion through microlending
On-device mobile agents for delivering essential services like education and healthcare

title: Agentic AI – the new frontier in GenAI An executive playbook
summary: Harnessing AI isn’t just about technology— it’s about unleashing unprecedented potential. In an era where speed, eﬃciency, and customer centricity dictate market leadership, organisations need to harness every tool at their disposal. Over the past couple of years, artiﬁcial intelligence (AI) has exploded onto the world stage, with companies and individuals across the globe rapidly adopting the technology. The GCC is playing a lead role in the space, with business leaders in the region exploring ways of integrating this rapidly developing technology into their operations. Generative AI (GenAI) is being recognised as a game-changer for innovation in the region, empowering enterprises by automating routine tasks, enhancing customer experiences and assisting in critical decision-making processes. Insights from our 27th Annual CEO Survey: Middle East ﬁndings have shown that 73% of CEOs in the Middle East believe GenAI will signiﬁcantly change the way their company creates, delivers and captures value over the next three years1. GenAI is poised to make a signiﬁcant economic impact, with estimates indicating that it could contribute between $2.6 trillion and $4.4 trillion annually to global GDP across various industries by 2030. In speciﬁc sectors, such as energy, investments in GenAI are expected to triple, from $40 billion in 2023 to over $140 billion by the end of the decade.
key_concepts: Harnessing AI to unleash unprecedented potential
Generative AI as a game-changer for innovation in the region
Automation of routine tasks and enhancement of customer experiences through GenAI
Agentic AI performs dynamic reasoning and decision-making, leveraging autonomous agents to resolve complex issues.
Agentic AI transforms manual labour into automated, AI-driven services, enhancing customer experience and efficiency.
Organisations can pay for specific outcomes delivered by AI agents, rather than purchasing traditional software licences or subscribing to cloud-based SaaS.

title: Big Data Analytics - Overview
summary: The volume of data has exploded to unimaginable levels in the past decade. Private companies and research institutions capture terabytes of data about their users' interactions, business, social media, and sensors from devices such as mobile phones and automobiles. The challenge is to make sense of this sea of data. Big Data Analytics involves collecting data from different sources, munging it for consumption by analysts, and delivering data products useful to the organization's business.
key_concepts: Making sense of large amounts of data
Collecting and processing data from various sources
Converting unstructured raw data to a usable format
Delivering insights and business value through data analysis
A cycle with different stages for organizing work and delivering clear insights
Understanding SQL is a key skill for big data analytics.
Data exploration phase is mandatory after cleaning and storing data.
Statistical techniques and plotting are used to understand the data.
Data preparation involves reshaping, imputation, outlier detection, normalization, feature extraction, and selection.
Modeling stage involves trying different models to solve business problems.

title: Brain Tumor Segmentation BraTS 2020 Dataset
summary: The document excerpt describes the Brain Tumor Segmentation BraTS 2020 Dataset, which involves segmenting gliomas in pre-operative MRI scans. The dataset requires labeling each pixel as part of a tumor area (1 or 2 or 3) or not (0). The sub-regions considered for evaluation are the enhancing tumor (ET), tumor core (TC), and whole tumor (WT). The provided segmentation labels have values of 1 for NCR & NET, 2 for ED, 4 for ET, and 0 for everything else.

title: Deep Learning
summary: Deep learning is the algorithm powering the current renaissance of artificial intelligence (AI). Its progress is not showing signs of slowing down. A McKinsey report estimates that by 2030, AI will potentially deliver $13 trillion to the global economy, or 16% of the world's current GDP. This opens up exciting career opportunities in the coming decade. However, deep learning can be daunting to learn. With the abundance of learning resources in recent years has emerged another problem - formation overload. This book aims to compress this knowledge and make the subject approachable. By the end of this book, you will be able to build a visual intuition about deep learning and neural networks.

title: Draft: Critical AI Security Guidelines, v1.1
summary: As artificial intelligence (AI) continues to revolutionize enterprises and security practices, ensuring security-focused controls for AI implementations is paramount. In this paper, multiple SANS experts and industry professionals delve into the critical categories of Generative AI, encompassing: Access Controls Data Protection Deployment Strategies Inference Security Monitoring Governance, Risk, Compliance (GRC). Our initial goal was to identify and establish technical security considerations for implementing and utilizing AI within an environment. However, as this space grows, our recommendations have evolved to address emerging challenges.
key_concepts: Ensuring security-focused controls for AI implementations is paramount.
Critical categories of Generative AI include Access Controls, Data Protection, Deployment Strategies, Inference Security, and Monitoring.
GRC (Governance, Risk, Compliance) is a critical aspect of AI security.
Models can be vulnerable to malicious code introduced through packaging.
Bad actors can create models with architectural backdoors that are difficult to remove.
Fine-tuning may not be enough to remove backdoors from models.
Pickle file attacks can exploit ML models and introduce malicious behavior.
Sleeper agents are deceptive LLMs that persist through safety training.

title: GenAI and the psychology of work
summary: Work is a central source of identity and meaning. The rapid and widespread adoption of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) is reshaping workplaces, challenging traditional human –machine boundaries and redefining the knowledge, task, and social characteristics of work. GenAI can benefit workers by enhancing their productivity and performance, but it also poses psychological threats to workers' needs for competence, autonomy, and relatedness.
key_concepts: Generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) is reshaping workplaces.
GenAI can demonstrate cognitive, creative, and interpersonal capabilities that challenge traditional human–machine boundaries.
The rapid adoption of GenAI threatens workers' needs for competence, autonomy, and relatedness.
GenAI helps automate repetitive processes, freeing up time for strategic and creative work.
GenAI increases worker enjoyment and meaningfulness of work by shifting focus toward social aspects.
GenAI satisfies relatedness needs by enhancing social skills and fostering positive emotional experiences.
GenAI replaces human interactions, leading to social isolation and erosion of social norms.
GenAI integration can increase objectification of workers and dehumanize coworkers.
Perceptions of human coworkers are assimilated toward GenAI systems, reducing prosocial motivation.
Workers' response to psychological threats and GenAI

title: Interview Questions
summary: Tokenization is the process of splitting text into smaller units called tokens, which can be words, subwords, or even characters. Effective tokenization allows models to handle various languages, manage rare words, and reduce vocabulary size, improving efficiency and performance. LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) is a parameter-efficient fine-tuning method that introduces new trainable parameters to modify a model's behavior without increasing its overall size.

title: The Illusion of Thinking: Understanding the Strengths and Limitations of Reasoning Models via the Lens of Problem Complexity
summary: This document explores the capabilities, scaling properties, and limitations of Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) through controllable puzzle environments. The study reveals that LRMs experience a complete accuracy collapse beyond certain complexities and exhibit a counter-intuitive scaling limit where their reasoning effort increases with problem complexity up to a point, then declines despite the complexity reduction. The work aims to provide insights into the reasoning traces’ structure and quality.
key_concepts: This work investigates the gaps in understanding the fundamental capabilities, scaling properties, and limitations of Large Reasoning Models (LRMs).
The study uses controllable puzzle environments that allow precise manipulation of compositional complexity while maintaining consistent logical structures.
The analysis focuses on not only final answers but also the internal reasoning traces, offering insights into how LRMs ‘think’.
Through extensive experimentation across diverse puzzles, it is shown that frontier LRMs face a complete accuracy collapse beyond certain complexities.
The work reveals an unexpected scaling limit: their reasoning effort increases with problem complexity up to a point, then declines despite the complexity reduction.
content_preview: Recent generations of frontier language models have introduced Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) that generate detailed thinking processes before providing answers.

title: Machine Learning For Absolute Beginners
summary: Machines have come a long way since the Industrial Revolution. They continue to fill factory floors and manufacturing plants, but now their capabilities extend beyond manual activities to cognitive tasks that, until recently, only humans were capable of performing. Judging song competitions, driving automobiles, and mopping the floor with professional chess players are three examples of the specific complex tasks machines are now capable of simulating. But their remarkable feats trigger fear among some observers. Part of this fear nestles on the neck of survivalist insecurities, where it provokes the deep-seated question of what if ? What if intelligent machines take over and replace human workers? The answer to these questions is not as simple as a yes or no.

title: Machine Learning for Marketers A COMPREHENSIVE GUIDE TO MACHINE LEARNING
summary: Machine learning is a term thrown around in technology circles with an ever-increasing intensity. Major technology companies have attached themselves to this buzzword to receive capital investments, and every major technology company is pushing its even shinier parent artificial intelligence (AI). The reality is that Machine Learning as a concept is as old as computing itself. As early as 1950, Alan Turing was asking the question, “Can computers think?” In 1969, Arthur Samuel helped define machine learning specifically by stating, “[Machine Learning is the] field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.” While the concept has been around for more than half a century, it has gained significant attention in recent years due to its potential applications in various industries. Machine learning can be used for tasks such as image and speech recognition, natural language processing, and predictive analytics. It has also been applied in areas like marketing, where it can help with customer segmentation, personalization, and recommendation systems.
key_concepts: Machine Learning is a term thrown around in technology circles with an ever-increasing intensity.
The reality is that Machine Learning as a concept is as old as computing itself.
Machine learning gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.
Developing technology that takes action based on learned patterns
Replicating human brain function through layered neurons and machine learning
Unsupervised learning to avoid human intervention
Using intuition to make choices in complex tasks
Reworking data in unlimited ways to find solutions
Marketing Automation: streamlining tasks with human hands, e.g. drip emails.
Machine Learning: next iteration for marketing automation systems, layering in ML capabilities.

summary: This course focuses on statistical learning theory, which roughly means understanding the amount of data required to achieve a certain prediction accuracy. Machine learning requires knowing the probability distribution from which the data is drawn, often with unknown parameters that have physical meanings.

title: Oversight Structures for Agentic AI in Public-Sector Organizations
summary: This document explores the challenges posed by agentic AI systems to traditional public sector oversight mechanisms. It identifies five essential governance dimensions for responsible deployment: cross-departmental implementation, comprehensive evaluation, enhanced security protocols, operational visibility, and systematic auditing. The study evaluates the capacity of existing oversight structures using a mixed-methods approach, consisting of a literature review and interviews with civil servants in AI-related roles. Findings suggest that agent oversight poses intensified versions of three existing governance challenges: continuous oversight, deeper integration of governance and operation...
key_concepts: The introduction of agentic AI systems intensifies existing challenges to traditional public sector oversight mechanisms.

Five governance dimensions essential for responsible agent deployment are identified: cross-departmental implementation, comprehensive evaluation, enhanced security protocols, operational visibility, and systematic auditing.
Existing oversight structures are evaluated via a mixed-methods approach consisting of a literature review and interviews with civil servants in AI-related roles.

Agent oversight poses intensified versions of three existing governance challenges: continuous oversight, deeper integration of governance and operational capabilities, and interdepartmental coordination.
Proposed approaches adapt institutional structures and design agent oversight compatible with public sector constraints.

title: Protecting society from AI misuse: when are restrictions on capabilities warranted?
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) systems will increasingly be used to cause harm as they grow more capable. To prevent some misuses of AI, we argue that targeted interventions on certain capabilities will be warranted. These restrictions may include controlling who can access certain types of AI models, what they can be used for, whether outputs are filtered or can be traced back to their user, and the resources needed to develop them.

The potential for LLMs to generate misinformation

title: A Closer Look at the Existing Risks of Generative AI
summary: This document presents a comprehensive analysis of real-world incidents related to Generative AI, mapping the causes, effects, and stakeholders involved. The study builds on prior taxonomies of AI risks and harms, focusing specifically on Generative AI failures and their associated impacts. Through an examination of 499 publicly reported incidents, the paper describes the prevalence of each type of harm, underlying failure mode, and affected parties, revealing that most incidents are caused by user-related issues but impact parties beyond the immediate users of the faulty system.
key_concepts: Explains the general-purpose nature of Generative AI and its expanding set of risks due to diverse applications.
Describes the construction of a taxonomy for Generative AI failures, mapping them to the harms they cause.
Reports on the prevalence of each type of harm, underlying failure mode, and affected stakeholders in 499 publicly reported incidents.
Highlights that most reported incidents are caused by user-related issues but impact parties beyond the immediate users of the faulty system.
Discusses the importance of understanding and addressing the risks associated with Generative AI to ensure its safe and responsible development, deployment, and use.

title: Large Language Models and Emotional Intelligence Tests
authors: Katja Schlegel1,2, Nils R. Sommere1& Marcello Mortillaro3
summary: This research investigates the emotional intelligence capabilities of large language models (LLMs) by examining their performance on standard emotional intelligence tests. The study found that LLMs, specifically ChatGPT-4, outperformed humans with an average accuracy of 81%, compared to human averages of 56% in original validation studies. The research also shows that LLMs can generate new test items for emotional intelligence tests, which were administered to human participants across five studies.
key_concepts: LLMs demonstrate expertise in diverse domains but their emotional intelligence is uncertain.
Research examines LLMs' ability to solve and generate performance-based emotional intelligence tests.
ChatGPT-4 outperformed humans on five standard emotional intelligence tests with an average accuracy of 81%.
ChatGPT-4 generated new test items for each emotional intelligence test, which were administered to human participants across five studies.

Original and ChatGPT-generated tests demonstrated statistically equivalent test difficulty but differences in other factors such as clarity, realism, diversity, internal consistency, correlations with vocabulary and external ability emotional intelligence tests were smaller than Cohen's d ± 0.25.
content_preview: Large language models are pro ﬁcient in solving and creating emotional intelligence tests

title: The emergence of AI ethics auditing
summary: This document explores the rapidly growing field of AI ethics and governance auditing in anticipation of regulatory efforts. The study, based on interviews with 34 individuals across seven countries, examines motivations, key activities, and challenges associated with AI ethics auditing in the private sector. It finds that audits follow financial auditing stages but lack robust stakeholder involvement, measurement of success, and external reporting. Audits are primarily focused on technical AI ethics principles like bias, privacy, and explainability. The document also discusses the challenges faced by auditors, including competing demands, resource constraints, lack of technical infrastru...
key_concepts: The emerging ecosystem of AI ethics and governance auditing has grown rapidly in recent years.
AI ethics audits follow financial auditing stages but lack robust stakeholder involvement, measurement of success, and external reporting.
Audits are hyper-focused on technically oriented AI ethics principles like bias, privacy, and explainability.
Auditors face challenges such as competing demands, resource constraints, lack of technical infrastructure, and ambiguity in interpreting regulations.
Despite these roadblocks, AI ethics and governance auditors are playing a critical role in the early ecosystem.
content_preview: Explores the rapidly growing field of AI ethics and governance auditing.

title: Transfer Learning
summary: Transfer Learning is a machine learning technique that leverages knowledge from one task (upstream) to enhance performance on another related task (downstream), particularly useful for tasks with limited data. The approach fine-tunes pre-trained upstream model weights to adapt them to the downstream task, with applications in computer vision and natural language processing. An example is fine-tuning a cat classifier to recognize dogs by utilizing shared features between the two animals.
key_concepts: Transfer learning utilizes knowledge gained from one task (upstream) to improve performance on another related task (downstream).
This approach is particularly beneficial when dealing with limited data for the downstream task.
Transfer learning involves fine-tuning the weights of a pre-trained upstream model to adapt it to the downstream task.
Applications include computer vision tasks like object detection and natural language processing tasks like sentiment analysis.
An example is fine-tuning a cat classifier to recognize dogs, leveraging the shared features between the two animals.
content_preview: Transfer Learning: A technique in machine learning that utilizes knowledge from one task to improve performance on another related task, particularly useful for tasks with limited data.

title: Transfer Learning in Deep Learning
summary: Transfer learning is a research problem in machine learning & deep learning that focuses on storing knowledge gained while solving one problem and applying it to a different but related problem. It involves using pre-trained models directly, as feature extraction preprocessing, and integrated into entirely new models. The goal is to leverage previous learning to understand the new concept or task.

title: Two types of AI existential risk: decisive and accumulative
summary: The conventional discourse on existential risks from AI focuses on abrupt, dire events caused by advanced AI systems. This paper contrasts the conventional decisive AI x-risk hypothesis with an accumulative AI x-risk hypothesis.
key_concepts: The conventional discourse on AI existential risks typically focuses on abrupt, dire events.
Decisive view: AI x-risk manifesting through a single, catastrophic event.
Accumulative hypothesis: AI x-risk manifesting gradually through incremental disruptions.
Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) represents capabilities comparable to human intelligence.
Artificial Superintelligence (ASI) denotes capabilities surpassing human intelligence.
Two types of AI existential risk: decisive and accumulative.
Instrumental sub-goals can lead to unintended consequences, such as eliminating humans or converting their bodies into paperclips.
The emphasis of this paper is on conventional discussions of AI x-risk.
The time axis is purely illustrative and not tied to specific units.
The zigzag pattern in the accumulative scenario represents potential local recoveries.

A McKinsey report estimates that by 2030, AI will potentially deliver $13 trillion to the global economy, or 16% of the world's current GDP. This opens up exciting career opportunities in the coming decade. However, deep learning can be daunting to learn. With the abundance of learning resources in recent years has emerged another problem - formation overload. This book aims to compress this knowledge and make the subject approachable. By the end of this book, you will be able to build a visual intuition about deep learning and neural networks.
key_concepts: The role of prediction in decision-making under uncertainty
How experience affects prediction and decision-making
Examples of prediction in language translation, business, and driving

title: Transfer Learning
summary: Transfer learning is a technique in machine learning that utilizes knowledge gained from one task (upstream task) to improve performance on another related task (downstream task). This approach is particularly beneficial when dealing with limited data for the downstream task. Transfer learning involves fine-tuning the weights of a pre-trained upstream model to adapt it to the downstream task. Applications include computer vision tasks like object detection and natural language processing tasks like sentiment analysis.

title: Recurrent Neural Networks
summary: Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are a class of neural networks that allow previous outputs to be used as inputs while having hidden states. They have several advantages, including the ability to process input of any length and computation taking into account historical information. However, they also have some drawbacks, such as slow computation and difficulty in accessing information from long ago. RNNs are commonly used in natural language processing and speech recognition.

title: La gestione del rischio nelle società quotate italiane
summary: Risk Ready Report 2025: An analysis of risks for Italian quoted companies through a thorough review of financial and sustainability documents published in 2024. The report aims to provide a clear and structured overview of risk disclosure, relating it to emerging trends and identifying areas of attention and opportunities for improvement.
key_concepts: La gestione del rischio nelle società quotate italiane è un tema fondamentale per le aziende.

Lo studio Risk Ready di Marsh McLennan analizza i rischi delle società quotate italiane attraverso una revisione approfondita dei documenti finanziari e di sostenibilità pubblicati nel 2024 e relativi all'anno precedente.

L'obiettivo è fornire una panoramica chiara e strutturata della disclosure dei rischi, mettendola in relazione con i principali trend emergenti e individuando sia le aree di attenzione sia le opportunità di miglioramento per una gestione sempre più strategica e consapevole.
Rischio di credito, liquidità, interesse e cambio è stabile in prima posizione.
La percezione dei rischi evolve nel tempo.
I rischi finanziari e esterni sono predominanti nella classifica.

Right join t1 and t2 to retrieve all rows from t2 and matching rows from t1.
Union two queries to combine rows from both queries.
Intersect two queries to return the common rows between both queries.

In operator to query rows in a list
